title: bosses should give their workers free fruit and bikes to make them feel better health secretary says
story: Matt Hancock suggested firms should also ensure employees have access to counselling to maintain their mental health.And he called on employers to make more effort to help ill workers get back to their jobs.Mr Hancock will this week set out a prevention strategy which aims to stop people getting ill - before they need expensive treatment.The strategy praises a Cornwall-based firm which gives all its employees free fruit in the office and cash to buy a bike, the Sundayreported.Mr Hancock said: Employers need to be more engaged when people arent well, getting them back to work.He said hi-tech gadgets could help Brits stay healthy by monitoring their bodies at all times and sending data to medical experts.The minister said: Where people consent and want to, you can go much further.For instance,you get your genome partially sequenced you can find outyou have a deficiency in a particular vitamin.A vitamin B deficiency leads to a higher instance of dementia but can easily be prevented by eating broccoli.And he suggested kitting out patients with a device which checks whether or not theyve taken the correct medication.

title: mh370 plane intact at bottom of indian ocean investigator claims
story: Author Larry Vance believes the planes fuselage survived the crash and is lying on the floor of the Indian Ocean.Vance dedicated a year and a half to researching his book MH: Mystery solved.He has now blasted the official investigation into the aircrafts disappearance claiming he knows the truth.The doomed jet vanished in March  over the Indian Ocean after setting off from the Kuala Lumpur en route to Beijing.All  passengers and  crew on board the Boeing  are missing, presumed dead.Vance told the Daily Star: The passengers ended up in the Southern Indian Ocean, and are at the bottom of the sea inside the sunken and intact fuselage.The Canadian-born investigator slammed the official investigation and expressed regret about how authorities in Malaysia hadnt gone back to the Southern Indian Ocean to follow his advice.He went on: I honestly believed that once the official investigation team saw the physical evidence that we discovered, and how we interpreted it accurately, they would change their minds about what they thought happened to MH.Unfortunately, and disappointingly, I was wrong.I am not sure why they continue to cling to their incorrect theories and analysis.He also dismissed the theory of Ian Wilson, an amateur investigator who claimed to have found the missing plane in the middle of the Cambodian jungle on Google Maps.Vance said there was no way the plane could have survived a crash into the jungle intact.Images from Google Maps show the outline of a large plane – which could simply be an aircraft flying directly below the satellite which photographed it.But video producer Ian is convinced of his findings and says he  intends to visit the sight to solve one of the greatest mysteries in aviation history.He told the Daily Star: Measuring the Google sighting, youre looking at around  metres, but there looks to be a gap between the tail and the back of the plane.Its just slightly bigger, but theres a gap that would probably account for that.

title: thousands of brits who earn living wage are handed 500 pay rise are you one of them
story: Around , workers will see their wages rise as a result of the new rate, set by an independent charity.In London, the Living Wage is rising to £. an hour, up from £..There are , employers which have committed to pay their workers the Living Wage - which is higher than the legal minimum.The rate, which is not to be confused with the national living wage dictated by the Government, is set with reference to the real cost of living.The rise from £. to £ outside London will mean that anyone working  hours a week on the Living Wage will get more than £ extra over the next year.The companies which have signed up to pay the rate include household names such as Google, Ikea, Nationwide, Oxfam and Heathrow airport.Several football clubs such as Liverpool and Everton are also committed to the movement.Tess Lanning of the Living Wage Foundation said: Responsible businesses know that the Government minimum is not enough to live on, and today’s new Living Wage rates will provide a boost for thousands of workers throughout the UK.“Employers that pay the real Living Wage enable their workers to live a le of dignity, supporting them to pay off debts and meet the pressures of rising bills.Heathrows finance boss Javier Echave added: Our colleagues are our most valued asset and deserve nothing less than the Living Wage.The Living Wage was launched in  to pressure employers to pay all their workers enough to live comfortably on.The rate is £. per hour higher in London to reflect the sky-high cost of living in the capital.In , George Osborne pinched the name for the national living wage, which is now the legal minimum for workers aged  or over.The NLW was raised to £. by Philip Hammond at last weeks Budget.

title: uk weather forecast five more storms before christmas
story: The UK has already been blasted by three named storms this year called Ali, Bronagh and Callum.But it seems that even more punishing wind and rain is on the way from Wednesday as a monster pressure vortex covering virtually all of the Atlantic Ocean barrels up to Britain.Simon Partridge at the Met Office said: There’s an upper trough over the Atlantic which will maintain low pressure and push in from the West through the week.“The thing is, we’ve got high pressure just to the East of us over northern Europe as well so these systems get pushed in from the Atlantic during the week and bump up against the high pressure.“So some of them will fizzle out over the West, but some of them will make their way all the way over to the East.“So it’s a fairly unsettled week ahead with the western UK in particular seeing the brunt of the wettest and windiest weather.And after this week, The Weather Company has forecasted that five more named storms will crash into the UK as Christmas nears, The Mirror reports.The powerful storms will be called Deirdre, Erik, Freya, Gareth and Hannah.If they do arrive, the additional five named storms will take s total to eight after Ali, Bronagh and Callum wreaked havoc earlier in the year.Leon Brown, head of meteorological operations at The Weather Channel, said: Four more named Atlantic storms are expected by early December, plus the risk of a fth named storm before Christmas.Travel disruption and wind gusts over mph in parts of the North and West are expected.Tomorrow will be a largely dry day with some patches of rain across north west Scotland and Northern Ireland.And it will be a generally be a dry evening for most places this Bonfire Night, leading to a dry start on Tuesday.But then a band of rain and the first blasts of strong winds will push in from the Atlantic later, making a wet and windy afternoon in the West of Britain.And the damp, blustery weather will continue for most of the UK on Wednesday - though temperatures will be higher than usual for this time of the year at around C in the South East.Later in the week and into the weekend will see a West East ide as unsettled weather grips the West of the nation, whereas the East should remain largely dry.The Met Office could not confirm that named storms will definitely hit before Christmas, as Simon explained: We generally only go out about as far as a week in that kind of detail.

title: queen mary saved wilfred smith from the trenches
story: They believe they would not be alive to do it were it not for an act of generosity by the Queen’s grandmother in one of the most moving tales of World War One.For these  men, women and children, aged two to , are the descendants of Wilfred Smith — a real le British version of movie character Private Ryan.In the war, which ended  years ago next Sunday, Wilfred’s mother Margaret saw all six of her sons go off to fight on the Western Front.As she waved goodbye to her youngest, -year-old Wilfred, she poignantly told women on the  at Barnard Castle station in County Durham: “Don’t have boys, they’ll only end up as cannon fodder.”That very day, in February , two of her sons were already dead, killed at the Somme.And by the following summer, mill worker Margaret and her husband John, a chimney sweep, had received five black-edged telegrams from the War Office, each one confirming that one of their boys had died in action.Three of them were never found and today their bodies still lie under the ploughed fields of Northern France and Flanders.But in August that year Queen Mary, we of King George V, read of Margaret Smith’s terrible story in a letter sent to Buckingham Palace.She vowed there and then that Wilfred would be ed home safe to his mother from the front line.Wilfred’s granddaughter Amanda Harrison takes up the story: “Vicar’s we Mary Bircham used to visit the slums of Barnard Castle, where the Smith family lived.“She befriended Margaret, who had  children. After her fth son, Alfred, died of his wounds in a hospital near Boulogne in July , Margaret was terried that Wilfred, her last boy, would also be killed.“So Mrs Bircham took the brave step of writing to Queen Mary and begging her to help save Margaret from any further sadness by bringing Wilfred home.”Amazingly, just days later, the Queen’s private secretary, Edward Wallington wrote back to say Her Majesty had contacted the War Office to find Private Smith in the trenches and order him home.The extraordinary events happened  years before Steven Spielberg made his World War Two film Saving Private Ryan, which echoed Wilfred’s story.Margaret and John Smith’s two years of hell had begun in September , when their -year-old son Robert was killed in the Battle of Flers-Courcelette, on the Somme.He had given up his job as a labourer to join the sixth battalion of his local regiment, the Durham Light Infantry, soon after war broke out in .Robert died just  weeks after arriving in France. He had been among  men who had wrongly been told the Germans were retreating from their position, known as the Starfish Line.At . on the morning of September , , in pouring rain, he was hit by enemy machine gun fire. He was taken to a casualty station where at first he and elder brother George, , who was in the same battalion, joked together. But three days later Robert died from his wounds. He was buried near the town of Albert.After his death, four brothers — George, John, Frederick and Alfred — came home on leave and posed for the photo above that would turn out to be their last together.Wilfred, then working as a mill hand, was not in the picture as he had not yet been called up.On Bonfire Night  George was in an attack on the Butte de Warlencourt, a ft prehistoric burial mound on the Somme, when he was shot through the head by a sniper as he waded through waist-deep mud.His body disappeared under the surface to be lost for ever.His name is carved into the wall of the Thiepval Memorial, along with , other British victims of the Somme who have no grave.Frederick, , was wounded on Christmas Eve  and was sent to recover at home, where he remained until February, .The following week, Wilfred joined up. Five months later, on the opening day of the third battle of Ypres, Frederick was killed.He and his comrades in the th Durham Light Infantry went over the top into a hail of machine gun fire.After driving the Germans from Imperfect Trench they pushed on but dozens, including Frederick, were mown down as they attacked a German fortication. Frederick has no grave but his name can been seen on the Menin Gate in Ypres, where every day since  the Last Post has been played.Margaret’s eldest son, John Stout, , who was married with two daughters, had been born out of wedlock.His name is carved in the Tyne Cot memorial in Belgium after he was killed on October ,  at Passchendaele and his body never found. The Smiths’ nightmare continued the following summer, when their fth son, -year-old Alfred, was wounded in battle on the Ardre river.He died of his wounds at a military hospital in Wimereux, near Boulogne, on July , .Just three weeks later, Queen Mary received the letter begging her to end Margaret Smith’s heartache and bring her last son home.By then Wilfred was a -year–old, battle-hardened Tommy who had fought the Germans hand-to-hand in the trenches south of Ypres.Queen Mary sent Wilfred home where he became a stonemason and chimney sweepHe had survived mustard gas attacks and was training for the final skirmishes of the war at Terdeghem, on the French-Belgian border, when a messenger arrived with orders from Army headquarters to pack his kitbag and go home.Military historian John Sheen, an expert on the Durham Light Infantry, said: “Mrs Smith’s story must have touched the Queen’s heart because taking a man from the line for personal reasons is extremely rare.”Wilfred ed home to Barnard Castle and became a stonemason and chimney sweep, like his dad John, who died in .Despite suffering chronic chest problems from the mustard gas attack for the rest of his le, he lived until he was  and raised five children with his we Hannah.Granddaughter Amanda, , says: “As children we knew a little bit about Wilfred’s amazing story. My mum would tell us some of it but Grandad did not really talk about it.“I think it was probably hard for him in some ways, as he was lucky to leave the war behind — though the people in Barnard Castle didn’t see it that way. Few people can imagine what it must have been like for him to lose five brothers.”On Sunday Wilfred’s daughter Dianne, , Amanda and her daughter Charlene, , son Craig, , and grandson Tommy, two, will plant poppy crosses at Barnard Castle’s war memorial, where the names of the tragic brothers are remembered.Sergeant Fritz Niland – Private James Ryan in the film – was part of the Allied D-Day operation to take back mainland Europe from the Nazis.But when the US military were led to believe that all three of Fritz’s brothers had been killed in action, they sent him home so the family would have one son left.The film, starring Matt Damon as Private Ryan, tells how heroic Captain John Miller, played by Tom Hanks, leads a group of soldiers to track down Ryan amid the chaos of war and send him home.But the real-le twist for Fritz Niland was that while his brothers Preston and Bob had both died fighting in France, his other brother, Edward, had wrongly been listed as having been killed.Edward had in fact been captured by the Japanese after parachuting into Burma in  and held as a prisoner of war.He was freed when the prison camp was liberated in May  and ed to live in the US until his death in  at the age of .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: student begs for a condom on facebook
story: University of Manchester student Jamie Innes, , was so desperate for a condom after a night out earlier this month he resorted to posting to a student Facebook page askinganybody could spare him one during his time of need.The IT student, from Coventry, posted online: Does anyone have a condom I am f***ing desperate This is not a joke I have less than an hour.And he was amazed when just  minutes later a contraceptive hero had obliged - dropping the contraception direct to him in Fallowfield, Manchester.Jamie said: When I posted online, it was a genuine request. I knew somebody would respond as everybody has banter in that group.“I was at the girls house and she was the one who had ran out of condoms. She messaged her house group chat, but nobody ended up replying.“I told her I was posting it on Facebook but she laughed, she found it hilarious. She didn’t think anybody would actually respond about it!Speaking about his saviour, Jamie said the fellow student messaged him directly and asked whether he was genuinely in need of a condom, saying we’ve all been in your shoes.And he said friend with benefits was left in stitches by the entire situation and was completely shocked when the generous stranger eventually arrived with a condom in tow to let them create some magic.Jamie said: He said he was on a bus back from uni and askedI’d been sorted and was only about five minutes away.He just had a spare on him, we had a quick chat when he dropped it off.I really needed one when I posted it, we waited about  minutes, but the magic had passed.We ended up waiting about  minutes more, and eventually the mood came back.“My dad found it pretty funny when he found out, but my mum doesnt know yet.”

title: student finds human poo car windscreen
story: Rachel Holmes, , is now trying to get to the bottom of whoever keeps fouling on her Renault Clio  when its parked outside her house in Swansea.The Swansea University student said: Someone has taken a dump on my car twice in ten days and I dont know why.Im not being funny but someone has s**t on my car for the second time in two weeks.I dont even know what to say.And she even went into detail about the nightmare of getting rid of the inexplicable dirty protest.Rachel, whos studying English and French, said that she had to get her mates to help her clean up the mess.She said: The first one was a bit runny at the beginning abut then it hardened and me and my friends had to chisel it off the windscreen.The second one was huge - HUGE! That person does need to see a doctor.But it was more fibrous so we could just chuck it on the floor.And Rachel was even able to work out the appalling s someone went to in the act of defiling her car.She explained: Im  per cent certain that it was human excrement, and they didnt even climb on the car to do it.It had been excreted and placed on my windscreen.I was so confused - I didnt realise people behaved like that.

title: brit fliers morning booze airports
story: An hour later the queue for the Brunel bar was  deep as drinkers joined in the early-morning party.Around them stag and hen dos were getting into the swing while waiting for flights to be called.It was a similar story in departure areas up and down the country.And the message from the people enjoying a breakfast tipple was the same — hands off our airport drinks.The fliers were outraged by Government plans to end the tradition of all-day boozing in airport terminals.As The Sun revealed last week, a review by the Home Office is expected to recommend that no alcohol is served before am.But Emily Golding,  — who was enjoying a am drink at Bristol on the way to Amsterdam to celebrate her hen do with friends and family — does not agree.She said: “They just need to do checks as people board the plane to make sure nobody’s been stupid about it.”Another drinker, Andy King,  — flying to Barcelona with ten others to celebrate their friend Darren Perrin’s th birthday — said: “Most people don’t drink at this time in the morning. I wouldn’tI wasn’t going away with the boys. We’re all just having a quick one. You can’t legislate for the idiots that cause the problems.”Mark Smith, , was heading from Bristol to Dublin for a pal’s stag do. He said: “If this legislation comes into place, it’s the airports that are going to be losing out on a heck of a lot of money.I’ve just spent £ on a round of  beers and a little bit of breakfast. It’s chucking money into the economy.”For some travellers, drinking helps with their fear of flying.Worried advertising boss Chris Andrews ordered his first beer at am before a flight from Manchester airport to Malaga. Chris, , from Cheltenham, said: “I’m a nervous flier so I want a beer to steady my nerves.”Nurse Michelle Nowell, , was also drinking at Manchester Airport with her mum Ann and pal Jane Bennett before flying to Tenere.Michelle said: “They shouldn’t be trying to spoil the start of people’s holiday just be- cause a few people can’t control themselves.”Bridget Kizza, , was having a cocktail at .am at Glasgow Airport on the way to Lanzarote. She said: “Alcohol can be more of a problem on the streets but it’s not as bad in airports.”The proposed crackdown would apply to duty free shops and restaurants, as well as the bars. So there would be no carrying on a bottle of booze ready for the first night of the holiday or having a quick glass of wine with breakfast.At Luton Airport the early fliers didn’t want their party spirit dampened.Champagne-swigging account manager Tracy Waldron, , of Peterborough, Cambs, who was heading to Lithuania with her pal Vicki, said: “I haven’t seen any rowdiness today but last time I was here there was a drunk man and that was at . in the morning. His we was really annoyed at him.”Punishments are already strong. Passengers who disrupt a flight can be jailed — andthey cause a flight to be erted they might be forced to pay up to £,.But not everyone thinks that planes and pints are a good mix. Ryanair has called for am to be the earliest that alcohol can be served because the number of booze-related disruptions on planes has doubled in two years.Oliver Bynon — who was flying to Amsterdam from Bristol to celebrate his st birthday with his brother Alex and two friends — agreed.He said: “You wouldn’t drink anywhere  this early. I’m only doing it because we’re celebrating my st. But I think the new law is a good idea.”Dad-of-two Brian Corrway, , travelling to Ireland from Glasgow with his we Linda and their three-month-old baby Oliver, also agreed that time should be called on early airport drinking.Accountant Brian said: “I’m in favour of it. It doesn’t really affect us but we have been in flights with people who are drunk and it’s not very good at that time in the morning.“I guess you do get a small number of people who spoil things for everyone and I don’t see another way of changing it other than limiting the amount people drink before they get on a flight.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: poppy sellers sent home uxbridge
story: John Paul Gaughan, , and Vic Emery, , were disgusted when they were told they didnt have permission to sell poppies at the intu shopping complex in Uxbridge on Saturday.The two heroes, who served a combined  years between them in the Army, were told the decision was made for public safety reasons.John and Vic carried on selling poppies by the main entrance ahead of the th anniversary of the end of World War One next Sunday.They were later invited to come back inside but refused on principle.John, who wears a poppy all year round, said: I am actually disgusted and I just could not get my head around it.I will keep volunteering for the Poppy Appeal as long as I still have breath in my lungs because I lost too many friends not to but I wouldnt go back to intu, I wont even shop there.I go to a veterans breakfast club and they askedanybody could volunteer to help issue poppies so I did assume it was all above board and sorted.John said he and his fellow volunteer had been selling poppies from am until about lunchtime when an intu employee askedthey had permission to be there and then informed them they would have to leave.Sun Online have approached intu Uxbridge for comment.In an official statement, intu Uxbridge said: We support and value the role of the Poppy Appeal, and every year we support its volunteers in raising all important funds.Yesterday, while the volunteers hadn’t notied us of their collection, which we kindly require all of our charity and volunteer organisations to do, we did have conversations with their team to allow them to remain in the centre, but they declined to do so.We are discussing this with the British Legion to ensure that this situation doesnt happen again and that they continue to be welcomed into the centre.General manager Laurie Taylor added: We have never had problems with poppy sellers before because previously they have come to speak to us first.For all we knew, these could have been rogue sellers even though they were wearing berets and medals.Despite Vics insistence that there were no rows, Mr Taylor added: The gentlemen were asked nicelythey would mind going as they did not have permission and refused. They started getting funny with us and taking pictures of us.

title: theres one man that is able to save us from mays brexit surrender
story: The half-in, half-out scheme would lock Britain into a customs union which prevents outside trade deals and leaves our £billion orce bill as just a down payment.Or so it seems from a series of whispered Downing Street leaks.Theresa May is so secretive she could yet surprise us all with a terric deal for Britain.In the meantime, Brexiteers are bracing themselves for a humiliating UK surrender.Ironically, fears of a botched treaty coincide with signs of growing dismay among EU member states over the shoddy treatment of a long-standing and respected ally.EU negotiator Michel Barnier has been rebuked publicly by EC President Jean-Claude Juncker for the way he has handled talks.Britain’s biggest non-EU allies — America, Japan and Commonwealth countries such as Australia — report “signs of panic” in the capitals of Europe.These focus not just on trade with Britain but on potent issues such as joint defence, intelligence and security.They come at a time of mounting EU anxiety over the disintegration of German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s authority, challenges to the euro from Italy and the rise of right-wing nationalists.Italy’s lethal threat to EU economic rules will come to a head just as we are due to leave next March.French President Emmanuel Macron warns Europe faces the worst instability since World War One.Yet far from capitalising on EU disarray, Mrs May appears ready to leave Britain stranded in what may turn out to be the ruins of the European Project.Her sop to Brexiteers — applying customs checks at factories, not borders — has backfired.“It means they were bluffing about a hard border with Northern Ireland all along,” says one.By taking us into a customs union, even temporarily, Mrs May will turn her back on allies eager for trade deals — led by American President Donald Trump.He planned to make it the highlight of next year’s state visit to the UK.World leaders are shocked by Britain’s cringing, long-winded and cackhanded negotiating style.“Just say you are leaving — and mean it,” says one. “That will get them to the table.”Alarm over “crashing out” is dismissed as scare stories.There is overwhelming confidence the world’s fth largest economy will thrive outside the EU.Ministers will be given a first glimpse of the plot stitched up between Barnier, the PM and Whitehall’s increasingly exhausted Olly Robbins.Mrs May will present them with a stark choice between a done deal and a Marxist Corbyn government.After two humiliating years of fumbled negotiation, this is a dismal prospect indeed.But there is another choice — a new leader ready to put the national interest ahead of naked personal ambition.It won’t be careerist Andrea Leadsom, nor Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt.Sajid Javid is damaged goods.Brexit supremo Dominic Raab wants Philip Hammond’s job as Chancellor.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt could seize the initiative, but he won’t act alone.So the hopes of many Tories are pinned on Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC, the breezy Brexiteer who torpedoed Mrs May’s first botched attempt to seal a deal.It was Cox who compared her Chequers blueprint to purgatory — the “second circle of Hell”.He is now marking her homework.Ministers want him to have the final say on the PM’s secret new deal — and for his views to be published.Cox is an eminent lawyer and constitutionalist.He is also a politician who has only recently snfed the sweet scent of political success.He has subsequently been tipped as a dark horse leadership contender.Having seen him in action at the Old Bailey, I think the national interest will come first.The .million who voted for British sovereignty will hope I’m right.“BORED” David Cameron, a nice man with poor judgment, is smarting from abuse over his dream of a peerage and a job as Foreign Secretary. Most blame him for Brexit.But his really unforgivable error was to see “Thatcher” as a dirty word and dodgy Tony Blair as The Master.As a result, he failed to win an outright majority in  and happily shacked up with treacherous Lib Dem Nick Clegg.He bet on another cosy coalition in , only to land a majority and the unwelcome obligation to deliver his promised referendum.Keep chillaxing, Dave.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john cannan broke promise to find suzy lamplugh
story: Arrogant sex killer Cannan, , offered the ray of hope to Suzys campaigning mother Diana when he was quizzed by police in  when cold case cops re-investigated the case as part of an operation codenamed Phoebus.Amazingly the seven VHS tapes were found dumped in a council run tip in south London and handed to The Sun on Sunday by a concerned member of the public who was shocked when he discovered what they contained.Questioned and Hammersmith police station in west London, over three days, Cannan even offers to take a lie detector test and a truth drug before offering a glimmer of hope to the Lamplugh family before brazenly taking it away.Evil Cannan tells detectives:Ive always said that I will help Mrs Lamplugh in any way I possibly can and Ive given my word, I wont break that word, I will keep that word. Mrs Lamplugh is very important, she obviously is but this isnt just about Mrs Lamplugh.I have a mother, I have a daughter and I have family of my own, whom, I love and who love me to. I have right to protect my own legal positionI genuinely feel that the state is engaged in improper activities and I believe that you are. He then menacingly warns cops:You are pushing me into a corner.He then steadfastly refuses to answer police questions despite them pointing out he has just offered to help the Lamplugh family - he even attacks Diana, who died in  by saying she had surrounded herself with people who do her no favours.Diana went to her grave convinced Cannan was involved in the  abduction and murder of estate agent Suzy who vanished after going to meet a mystery man called Mr Kipper at a house she was selling in Fulham.Cannan told cops Diana had already convicted meof murdering Suzy and even after three jail interviews where he is serving le for the murder of Shirley Banks in , the attempted kidnap of Julia Holman the previous night and the rape of a woman in Reading a year earlier continues to deny any involvement.At one point in the tapes Cannan confesses: I have committed crime, I have done many things wrong in my le, things that believe me I am genuinely sorry for, one or two things I havent even been caught for. Well spoken Cannan even jokes with cops recording the interviewsthey can make him a Genesis tape.After Operation Phoebus ended, the Crown Prosecution Service decided there was insufficient evidence to charge Cannan. But in November  the Met took the unusual step of naming him as their prime suspect for Suzys murder. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universities blasted as not value for money
story: A report published by the Commons Education Committee calls for a sharper focus on the teaching of skills and more support for disadvantaged students.Committee chair Rob Halfon demanded an expansion of degree apprenticeships as well as a fresh look at excessive vice chancellor pay.He said: “The blunt reality is that too many universities are not providing value for money and that students are not getting good outcomes from the degrees for which so many of them rack up debt.“Too many institutions are neither meeting our skills needs or providing the means for the disadvantaged to climb the ladder of opportunity.”The report suggests the “unjustiably” excessive salaries of vice-chancellors have become the norm rather than the exception.It also says they do not represent value for money for students or taxpayers.In the report MPs also say they are “deeply concerned” by the fall in part-time and mature learners.They say universities must offer more flexible learning, including credit transfer, work placements and a move away from the traditional three-year undergraduate approach.The rise in tuition fees in  and the introduction of maintenance loans has led to students from the poorest backgrounds accruing debts over a three-year degree of around £,.The report says the Government should reinstate the means-tested system of loans and maintenance grants.Mr Halfon added: “Our higher education system needs to have a much sharper focus on developing skills.“This could make an important contribution to filling the nation’s skills gaps and solving the UK’s productivity puzzle.“Russell Group universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, should rise to this challenge, up their game and rocket-boost degree apprenticeships.”A Department for Education spokesman said: “Our reforms have seen record rates of disadvantaged -year-olds attending our world-class universities and we want this to continue.That’s why we are pleased to see universities and further education colleges planning to spend more than £ million on measures to improve access and outcomes for disadvantaged students.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make story: NewsForeign nationals to be allowed to serve in British Army eventhey dont live in BritainEligibility restrictions are being signicantly loosened in a bid to fill shortfalls in recruitmentShareCommentsBySam Blewett:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailForeign nationals will be eligible to join the Armed Forces in greater numbers, Ministers will announce, as British residency requirements for service are set to be scrapped. The Ministry of Defence will remove the need for Commonwealth citizens to have lived in the UK for five years before applying for service, it will be announced on Monday. An extra , personnel from oversees are hoped to be enlisted to the the Navy, Army and Air Force every year. The move comes as the Armed Forces struggle to recruit enough personnel to fill a shortfall in their ranks. Applicants from nations including India, Australia, Canada and Fiji will be considered for all roles in the forces, without having lived in the UK. Until now, they had to have resided in Britain for five years and their recruitment was capped at a maximum of  per year. The Army will begin the admissions from early next year, while the Navy and RAF will commence the process immediately. Other than the Nepalese Gurkhas and applicants from the Republic of Ireland who can enrol under a special arrangement, those from outside the Commonwealth will still need British citizenship to apply. In April, a National Audit Office report said the full-time military was running at a .% shortfall. An extra , regulars and , engineers were needed to fill the largest gap in a decade, the report added, while intelligence analysts and pilots were also in demand.

title: union chiefs slam theresa conning
story: NewsUnion chiefs slam Theresa May for conning low-paid workers with boost to living wageEXCLUSIVE: Frances OGrady of the TUC says people will still "struggle to keep their heads above water" after living wage goes upShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  NOV NewsTop union chiefs have slammed Theresa Mays  promises of wage hikes for low-paid workers "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is “conning” millions of low-paid workers with her promised wage hike, Britain’s top union chief declares today. The Prime Minister will boast in a speech today that she is committed to “making work pay” by boosting the national living wage to pound. an hour. But in a stunning attack, TUC boss Frances O’Grady warns that by claiming this is a “living wage”, Mrs May is in fact “conning the public”. Writing for The Mirror, Ms O’Grady says: “Many people earning that wage will still struggle to keep their heads above water. “Just paying for the basics – food, housing, childcare, transport – will be a battle.” The Tories announced the pay rise last week in the Budget.  They will hike the National Living Wage once again – up from pound. – but the increase won’t affect everyone. The % hike will come into force from April, and will be given to around .million workers. But Ms O’Grady says it is still below what many need to live on – what she calls a “real living wage”.And it doesn’t apply to those under  either. She writes: “By claiming that’s a living wage, they’re either conning the public or conning themselves.” In a swipe at the PM, Ms O’Grady blasts: “Instead of helping out the lowest paid, Theresa May and her government have chosen to give tax cuts to corporations and the wealthy.” The Resolution Foundation revealed that Britain’s richest households will gain  times more cash from last week’s Tory Budget than the poorest families.The “real” Living Wage paid voluntarily by some employers will climb to pound an hour – giving more than , workers a pay boost, it was announced on Sunday. Comment By Frances OGrady, TUC General Secretary The Prime Minister will give a speech on Monday claiming that her government is committed to “making work pay”. But try telling that to the millions of hard-working people struggling to make ends meet in Britain today. In-work poverty has rocketed since the Tories took office in .The number of kids growing up below the breadline - despite have at least one parent in work - has shot up by a third to three million. And what has the government done about it Well, they rebranded the minimum wage as the National Living Wage. And in last week’s budget, the rate went up to pound. an hour. But by claiming that’s a living wage, they’re either conning the public or conning themselves. Because across Britain, many people earning that wage will still struggle to keep their heads above water. Just paying for the basics - like food - will be a battle. That’s why we at the TUC are calling on all employers to pay the Real Living Wage. It’s a higher rate , calculated to give workers a wage packet they can build a decent le on. But instead of helping out the lowest-paid, Theresa May and her government have chosen to give tax cuts to the wealthy and corporations. Britain’s richest households will gain  times more cash from last week’s budget than Britain’s poorest families. After nearly a decade of austerity, working people have had enough.

story: NewsBoys aged  and  both injured by SAME bullet in horric drive-by shooting at childrens Halloween partyThe two boys, aged  and , were about to attend a childrens Halloween party when they were gunned down in a street in BirminghamShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTwo teenage boys were injured by the same bullet in a drive-by shooting on Saturday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo teenage boys were injured by the same bullet after they were hit in a drive-by shooting as they stood outside a Halloween party. The -year-old and -year-old boys were gunned down outside a family members home in Birmingham on Friday night as they attended a childrens Halloween party. The boys knocked on the door of the house around .pm and as they waited for someone to open it they were shot at by the gunman. A bullet pierced the -year-old chest - narrowly missing his vital organs. It then lodged in the stomach of his -year-old friend. Distraught relatives opened the door to find the two boys bleeding in a heap on the ground.  Both remain in hospital in a serious but stable condition. The younger boy underwent surgery to have the bullet removed from his stomach on Saturday. Detectives are carrying out round the clock enquiries to find whoever fired the gun which includes extensive CCTV analysis being carried within the area. The shot is believed to have come from someone in a car who then fled the scene.  West Midlands Police, Detective Superintendent Maria Fox said: We as a police force, and the community as a whole, are absolutely shocked, appalled and outraged that two children have been shot at and seriously injured. All gun crime is completely unacceptable but the fact that two teenage boys, who were just out and about enjoying the festivities have suffered pain at the hands of a weapon is even more galling. There can be no excuse or justication to shoot towards young people and it makes us all the more determined to catch the coward who did this. I can assure everyone that we wont stop until we bring them to justice. We have a number of active lines of enquiry but at this stage we dont believe the boys were deliberately targeted. But that is no solace for them as they recover from their injuries and psychological torment this will have undoubtedly brought.  I am particularly keen to hear from anyone who saw a car behaving suspiciously between around -.am maybe driving slowly or repeatedly seen in the area. We believe there were a lot of other vehicles in the area at the time and we need those drivers to come forward - especiallythey have dash cam footage. No arrests have been made and police are trying to establish a motive and trace the gunman.

Steff Barnett, , who was born Steve, knew for many years she was a gay woman trapped in a man’s body. But she only started the process of changing gender after the couple’s two sons had left home. And despite the problems it has posed, nurse Lynne, , decided to remain with the person she married. They no longer have an intimate physical side to their relationship but say they are still happy together.  Radio presenter Steff said: “Lynne misses her husband desperately... “The guilt was horric. I felt as though I’d let Lynne down. I love her passionately even now. “She’s stayed by me, she was brave enough to do that, even though she’s just about lost her husband. “There’s this huge love thing going on between us. It’s almost a meshed soul but something is twisting it, trying to pull it apart.” Lynne said: “When he started to transition I knew there was no turning back. “But I loved Steve enough to know this was the only way forward.” She added that as far as she is concerned they will always stay married. The pair, from Bradley Stoke, Bristol, met in a pub in  when Lynne was , and they watched Hollywood movie Shaft on their first date.  But Lynne was not initially convinced by her suitor – leading to several awkward months. She said: “He would come to my house and I would hide in the back room and my mum would go absolutely crazy. She would say ‘he’s come round to see you, you have to go. I’m not going to tell him you’re not in’.” The pair soon saw past their dferences and married within a year of those first dates. Two weeks later the husband had a confession for Lynne – he enjoyed wearing women’s clothes. Steff said: “I couldn’t use the term gender dysphoria because I had no clue what that was. “But neither of us knew the consequences of what was coming.”  Lynne added: “It wasn’t once said ‘I think I’ve been born in the wrong body’. We thought it was a sexual thing [he was] going through. “It didn’t bother me he wanted to put on stockings or suspenders or a skirt. I didn’t even think about it because it wasn’t something that was done all the time.” Apart from Lynne knowing, Steff kept it a secret about wearing women’s clothes for decades. The couple had two children and Steff feared living openly as a woman while their sons were young because of concerns over playground bullying. She said: “We knew how cruel schoolkids could be andI had transitioned when I was younger it would have wrecked their lives I’m sure. “Every waking moment I had to suppress this feeling of ‘I’m not me’... I’m not me’. “My thoughts and my feelings were dragging at me constantly.”  In  Steff decided the time was right to think about transitioning. She said: “We had three years of talking and talking to try and sort the issue. I don’t think I would be hereI didn’t transition. “So Valentine’s Day when I went in I had surgery I walked out with Lynne and I just whooped for joy. “I took my first breath outside... It was a very emotional moment.” But Steff admits things are not perfect. Speaking to the BBC, she said: “I miss the intimacy. I really do. But Lynne can’t make that leap. “Lynne had to go through the loss of her husband and then after that I had to go through the loss of my we.” Lynne misses having a man’s arms around her.  The mum said: “Steff is gay, she’s liked women, she’s always liked women. I’ve always been  per cent heterosexual. I miss him [Steve] every day. “To have a man’s hands around you, kissing you, protecting you. “I’m not in her head to understand to see how she thinks. And she’s not in my head to feel what I’ve lost.  “She is a very tactile person who likes to be cuddled and kissed and hug and hold hands and I can’t do that. I just can’t do it.” Lynne added: “She says ‘well you can cuddle your friends when you’re down’ but my friends have always been in that female form... They weren’t my husband to start with.” Since transitioning, Steff has become a presenter at BCfm Radio, hosting a weekly show on Fridays.  Steff said: “I am so, so happy. It was always a dream to get into radio. That didn’t happen until I transitioned. I am much more confident. “And I’m probably the happiest I’ve ever been in my entire le. And I’m now me. “We still love each other. And I guess that’s what got us through this.” Lynne said: “There have been other people in my le but there isn’t anyone that I would want to be with more than I want to be with Steff.  “Our marriage certicate still says Steve Barnett and Lynne Hogan and as far as I’m concerned that is a sacred piece of paper to me and that’s how it will always be. “We’ve had a hell of a journey. Ups and downs, good and bad and I just can’t see us just not being together. “You just count your blessings and think that things could be so much worse. I’m one of the lucky ones.”The couple told their story to BBC Inside Out West. It is on BBC in the West at .pm on Monday, and afterwards it is available on BBC iPlayer.

title: hero sir rosslyn wemyss saved
story: NewsHero Sir Rosslyn Wemyss saved hundreds of lives by cutting First World War short by ½ hoursEXCLUSIVE: Wemyss, the British delegate at the signing of the Armistice, fought against Lloyd Georges plan to end the war at .pmShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  NOV NewsAdmiral Hope, General Weygang, Admiral Wemyss, Marshal Foch and Captain Marriot after signing the peace agreement "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is one of the most haunting and shymemorable dates in our history books – the “eleventh hour of the shyeleventh day of the eleventh month” of  – the day the Great War ended. ButPrime Minister David Lloyd George had his way, that shyunforgettable time and date  years ago this Sunday would not have been so evocative. Worse, it would have cost thousands of lives. A century ago Admiral Sir Rosslyn Wemyss, First Sea Lord – and “Rosie” to his family – was picked as the British delegate at the signing of the Armistice.  The agreement would bring an end to four years of the most bitter and bloody fighting Europe had seen. In a rickety railway carriage, a former dining car turned makesht office, parked up in woodland in Compiegravegne, in northern France, Sir Rosslyn joined the Supreme Allied Commander, Frenchman Marshal shyFerdinand Foch, and the German delegation. After much shuttling between that carriage and the Germans’ own – parked a few metres along the track – the shyArmistice was signed at .am and the ceasefire announced at am.  But today, Sir Rosslyn’s great-great-nephew, Michael Wemyss, , reveals Lloyd George wanted the shyceasefire at .pm, rather than the famous th hour. It would have a been a costly choice... He says: “He was instructed by Lloyd George to ensure the Armistice took effect at .pm. “The story is, Rosie rang King George V and between them decided there was no point holding off, so they brought it forward to the th hour, am.  “Lloyd George wanted to announce it in the Commons and take the glory. George V announced it and Lloyd George had the rug pulled out from under him. “Every hour saved lives.” But siding with the king against the prime minister cost Sir Rosslyn, , dear. “Lloyd George was furious, and shywithheld Rosie’s pound, grant – all the service chiefs got a thank you. They all got earldoms too!” says Michael.  “Rosie was furious. He felt what he had done was to everyone’s benefit other than Lloyd George personally and this was a vendetta.” Sir Rosslyn’s shydecision, backed by George V, a cousin and friend, with whom he had served in the navy, wasn’t his only shyleshyshysaving action during the First World War. He was responsible for getting all the British and Australian troops out of Gallipoli in Turkey in , after their campaign failed spectacularly. “When the army decided to retreat he managed to get all the soldiers off the peninsula without a single death,” says Michael proudly. Alongside him was Captain John Peter Ralph Marriott – and it was to Marriott that Sir Rosslyn turned to assist him at the momentous signing of the Armistice.  Today, his grandson Charles Marriott, , says his ancestor was also always hugely proud of his presence that day. And it was he who phoned the King’s personal secretary to reveal the shydocshyshyument had been signed. “It took him half a day desperately trying to get through,” Charles reveals.  Then only , Charles was gted the blotting paper that was used to dry the ink of the signatures as a memshyento. He always recalled the tense shyatmosphere in the carriage – and the aggressive exchanges between the rather cocky Allied contingent, and their crushed enemy. The Germans had been forced to hand over all their artillery, machine guns, naval fleet, and air force.  “There was quite a lot of rudeness in the carriage,” says Charles. “The German delegation said, ‘We need an Armistice, our people are starving’ – the Navy had blockaded the German ports. And Wemyss told them, ‘You look fat enough!’ “The German replied, ‘As you well know, Admiral, we are the people who don’t suffer in these situations’.” On the French side Eacuteric Beacutecourt-Foch, great-grandson of Marshal shyFerdinand Foch, says his ancestor had a very personal reason for relishing his signing of the Armistice. Foch lost his own son, as well as his son-in-law, Eacuteric’s grandfather, on August , , during the Battle of the shyFrontiers when , French soldiers were killed in less than  hours.  “He did not learn of their deaths for a number of months, the armies were in retreat and it was a great mess,” says Eacuteric, . “News didn’t get through.” Movingly, family man Foch, in deep mourning, wrote to his we nearly ever day during the conflict. “It must have meant all the more to him to finally sign the Armistice,” says Eacuteric of that incredible moment. It was Foch’s carriage where the signing took place – and  years later it was also the location of another historic moment.  When France signed an armistice with the Germans in  during the Second World War, Adolf Hitler ordered that it take place in the same carriage in Compiegravegne, so the Germans could lord it over their enemies. Then the carriage was taken to Berlin and exhibited – until in , as the Nazis realised defeat was coming, they blew up it up in one final act of revenge.

The mum-to-be impressed fashion-lovers with her incredible looks - covering everything from comfy casual to red carpet glam from high street names, as well as designer brands. And communication coach Robin Kermode believes the pregnant duchess, , used her strategically picked attire to signal her strongly held beliefs. In total, it is estimated Meghans Down Under tour wardrobe cost pound,. The items of clothing with signicant meanings behind them include her pumps created out of recycled plastic water bottles, and jeans made by female victims of human trafficking and sexual exploitation. With the world of the eyes upon her, some of Meghans outfits have unsurprisingly sold out as fans rush to snap them up. The jeans made by female victims of sexual exploitation  On several occasions during the overseas tour, Meghan opted to wear jeans from Outland - including the Harriet pair, pictured above. The Australian brand was founded by James Bartle after he saw first-hand how human traffickers prey on vulnerable young girls in order to service the sex industry. Determined to making a change, James learnt that once a girl has been rescued and supported through her recovery, a sustainable career path is vital for securing her future. He created the Denim Project, to enable those girls who demonstrated an interest in sewing to put their new skills to use. Outlands team of seamstresses offer positions to those at risk of falling into poverty, and has broadened its mission to set a standard for the treatment and remuneration of young female workers in the garment manufacturing industry. It also sources ethically and environmentally sound raw materials, from organic cotton pocket linings to recycled packaging. After the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their engagement, they asked people who wanted to mark the occasion to donate to charities they had picked instead of giving them wedding gts. One of these charities included the Myna Mahila Foundation, which empowers women in Mumbai’s urban slums, by providing them with a trusted network, where they are supported professionally and personally to help them grow as iniduals and businesswomen. Thus Meghans Outland jeans reflect her desire to help vulnerable women which she has spoken so openly about. The French fashion brands founders, Seacutebastien Kopp and Franccedilois-Ghislain Morillion visited clothing and food factories in South America, Asia and Australia while running a nonprofit group — and were appalled by what they saw. So in , they founded Veja in France with the vision of making trainers using the most ecological materials and ethical suppliers they could find. Fashion fans were delighted when they saw Meghan wearing a pair and the duchess is keen on environmental and conservation causes. The recycled plastic bottle pumps  Meghan wore Rothys flats twice on tour, including during a beach clean-up in Melbourne. The pumps are made from recycled plastic water bottles that would otherwise have been destined for landfill - and have been dubbed the most politically correct shoes on the planet by Vogue. The insoles on all of Rothy’s shoes contain recycled foam the rubber soles are made without environmentally stressful black carbon. The yarn comes from plastic and even the packaging’s made from post-consumer recycled materials. Meghan supports charity Surfers Against Sewage, which is a national marine conservation and campaigning charity. It inspires, unites and empowers communities to take action to protect oceans, beaches, waves and wildle. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the charity said: Our work as a national marine conservation charity empowers tens of thousands of volunteers annually to protect beaches for everyone. We are currently focused on tackling plastic pollution and this support will help us move towards our vision of Plastic Free Coastlines.” So it is very fitting Meghan wore the pumps during the beach visit - signalling her passion to protecting the sea from plastic. The sustainable brand  The Duchess of Sussex wore a stunning custom-made silk wool cocktail dress in dark navy by Gabriela Hearst at Government House in Wellington. The sustainable luxury brand is based on a less is more approach. Gabriela is a notable feminist designer and political activist. She wanted to create a brand that reflects a slower pace and process: where things are made with care and detail, where tradition is more important than trend, where there is a purpose to every piece, according to her website. She takes into consideration where materials come from and who is making them. Meghan wore the dress to deliver a speech to honor the th anniversary of female suffrage. The empowering dress  Meghan looked sensational when she wore a beautul white Theia dress for dinner with the King and Queen of Tonga. The label is inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, who had an incredible power to turn everything that she gazed on to light. The Theia dresses are designed to make women feel confident – similar to Meghan’s beliefs. The website explains about their collection: Inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, this evening wear, bridal and day dress collection was created to bring out every womans inner goddess. One of the original Titans, Theia, who ruled during the Greek Golden Age, possessed the incredible power of light which radiated from her sparkling eyes. All that she gazed upon glittered, becoming luminous and radiant. She imbued gold and silver with their shine. She gave diamonds their fire and rubies and emeralds their sparkle. Her three children Helios the sun, Celene the moon, and Eos the dawn, all continue to bring light in to the world everyday. The woman who wears Theia will be filled with confidence knowing her dress fits wonderfully and looks beautul on her, thus naturally allowing her inner goddess to shine. title: man saved taking life bridge
story: NewsMan saved from taking his own le on bridge hits out at vile online trolls who said "jump"The -year-old says he was shocked when he went on social media and saw insensitive comments from driversShareByAlexandra RuckiChris kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsDrivers were furious over the traffic disruption and didnt care about the mans situation "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad-of-four who was stopped from taking his own le has hit out at online trolls who write cruel and disparaging comments at those in crisis. The man came close to falling from a bridge over the M but was saved when an ambulance crew spotted him as they passed underneath it. Police arrived moments later, shut the motorway and spoke to the -year-old, who has asked not to be named, until he came down. He later went on social media and was shocked by some of the insensitive comments from drivers who were outraged over the traffic disruption and unconcerned about his well-being, he told the Manchester Evening News.  They included Just jump I need to get home, Make sure he gets carted away before I start work and Tell him to get a move on. The man was taken to hospital after he was talked down from the bridge but was left alone in a room and went back to the bridge just hours after. The same police officers brought him back down and stayed with him in the hospital room overnight.Months on, he said he feels awful that police officers were taken off the streets that night and that traffic disruption was caused by the incident. But some of the comments he saw on social media made him feel much worse. Now, he wants to appeal to social media users to think twice before making an off-hand comment - in a bid to raise awareness of the devastating consequences it could have.  He said: To those posting on social media, just think - you never know that could be your mum, or dad up there. Whatthat person looks at the article, reads all of these comments and then goes back out there  It a shame that society feels like that. There is still a lot of stigma about mens mental health and mental health in general. Last week I saw two friends and I was talking to them about when I came out of hospital. They were with a girl Id never met before and she said oh you are a psycho as well. Whatthat was somebody   It could go and set them back. I am thick-skinned, but when I see the comments made about other people I get upset about it. He also explains there is one phrase that he finds particularly damaging, often said to men in his situation. The man said: When it is men people say man-up. My girlfriend at the time kept saying that. It really grates, it hurts inside. It feels like my stomach drops, it makes you feel worse. As a man you are supposed to be one type, but I am a bit feminine - I like things tidy. Saying it to someone suffering from mental health doesnt help. Since he tried to take his own le the man has received treatment at a mental health unit and is now living in supported housing. During his first week out of the hospital he says support workers visited every day, but since then no-one has been to see him.  He was diagnosed with emotionally unstable personality disorder at a young age. Those with the disorder can experience very intense emotions, feel deeply about what others think and can behave impulsively. The man has been told by medics he needs to undergo intensive therapy, but it has never materialised. He said: I have never had therapy. I have spent six years waiting for it. There is that many people getting sectioned daily you just get lost in the system. There is no support, they wont help people until you are suicidal. I am on a mixture of tablets for my mental health and Codeine pain killers. Sometimes I am that knackered I dont go out a lot. I cant work. I was working before, full time. While theres been a lack of mental health services and support since, the dad is hugely grateful to the emergency services who attended the bridge that day. He credits the police officer who spoke to him, and the ambulance crew that first spotted him, with saving his le. The man said: If people hadnt come out I dont think I would be here. I am grateful, especially to the police woman that talked me down, who was really nice. She came back and got me again. She was really lovely, came to check on me as well after to seeI was alright. It couldve been a dferent storyit was a man, she was softly spoken and calmed me down. Its not the first time Ive attempted to take my le, but its the first time I have in three years. If you are going through same thing go and get help. But I know myself, its OK saying get help to others, but when you are in that mind frame you are not thinking about your children. All you think about is ending your le. With me it is emotional, I get angry, I dont feel sociable like everybody , making plans stresses me out. There needs to be more information out there, about what to do. Dont judge peopleyou put a comment up on something like that , think whatthat is your own kids  Elizabeth Simpson, Service Director at Manchester Mind, said: Not all suicides are mental health related but the vast majority are - and unfortunately situations like this show that there remains a lack of understanding about suicide. There is still a lot of stigma, but people in crisis need support and understanding, not judgement and impatience. “With one in every four people experiencing a mental health problem each year there has never been a greater need for services, and Manchester Mind’s vision is of a city that promotes good mental health and that treats people with mental health problems positively, fairly and with respect. Helplines and websitesSamaritansoperates a -hour service available every day of the year. If you prefer to write down how you’re feeling, oryou’re worried about being overheard on the phone, you can email Samaritans at jo@samaritans.org. Childlineruns a helpline for children and young people in the UK. Calls are free and the number won’t show up on your phone bill. PAPYRUSis a voluntary organisation supporting teenagers and young adults who are feeling suicidal.

story: NewsRussian GRU spies branded Monty Pythonesque on th birthday after string of cock-upsEXCLUSIVE: Once-lethal secret service has been ridiculed following the Salisbury poisoning disasterShareCommentsByAndy Lines:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsRussias GRU agency has caused the Kremlin great humiliation ahead of its th birthday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussian GRU spies have been branded Monty Pythonesque on th birthday after string of cock-ups The once lethally efficient agency, behind the bungled Salisbury Novichok poisoning, has been ridiculed and was branded “unprofessional and Monty Python-esque” by a military expert. The trail left by double agent Sergei Skripal’s would-be assassins Alexander Mishkin and Anatoly Chepiga in Salisbury in March humiliated the Kremlin. The GRU has also left its tracks on the cyber-attack in The Hague as well as the hacking of the US presidential campaign, the German federal parliament’s network and prosecutors probing the shooting down of an plane over Ukraine.  Ex-NATO chief Hamish de Bretton-Gordon called Russia’s equivalent of our MI “inept, unprofessional and slapdash responsible for a series of debacles and almost Monty Python-esque.” He said: “The GRU is in meltdown. There have been purges. Our intelligence agencies are watching with wry shyamusement at how bad they are.”  Russian President Vladimir Putin is privately furious with the Moscow-based GRU. story: NewsSarah Wellgreen: Mysterious hooded figure is being hunted in search for missing mum-of-fivePolice searched Thames mudflats in the hunt for Sarah Wellgreen after grainy CCTV footage of a hooded figure emergedShareByMilo Boyd:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsSarah Welgreen "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGrainy CCTV footage of a hooded man prompted police to send out specialist ers, its emerged - as the hunt for a missing Sarah Wellgreen continues. As concerns for her welfare grew hundreds of people volunteered to join the search party and the police issued a renewed appeal. Last week black and white images taken from a CCTV camera came to light. Having left the vehicle and walked towards a wall running along the riverbank, the man s to his car after less than a minute. On Friday Kent Police reissued its appeal for any CCTV and dashcam footage taken within a five-mile radius of New Ash Green on the night of  to  October. story: NewsSnapchat yob who pelted vulnerable woman with flour and eggs says HES now too scared to leave his homeCohan Semple says hes received "death threats from random people" after the sickening attack on mum-of-one Janice Morris in Bury St Edmunds, SuffolkShareByLouis SmithSophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCohan Semple humiliated the vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage yob who humiliated a vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs is now too scared to leave his home, it is reported.Cohan Semple says hes struggling to leave his house amid death threats following the sickening attack on -year-old Janice Morris. The teenager was among five boys who targeted Janice as she sat on a park bench in Suffolk in what a court heard was a despicable attack.An image showing them smiling and pointing at their cowering victim sparked widespread revulsion after being posted on Snapchat and Facebook. Until this week, the boys - all between  and  years old at the time - had had their identities protected because of their age. But Semple turned  last week, meaning he could be unmasked for the first time. Speaking out yesterday, the teenager - who pleaded guilty to threatening behaviour - described how he has received death threats from strangers.He told Sun Online: I’m struggling to leave the house at the moment. Since those pictures have gone on Facebook, I’ve had death threats from random people. Askedhe wanted to apologise for the attack in Bury St Edmunds, he reportedly said he was not ready because of the death threats sent to him online.Semple and his friends faced online abuse and direct threats from people who were sickened by the picture after it was shared online. Yesterday, presiding magistrate Simon Islett told the younger members of the group they could have faced jail termsthey were a few years older. He described the incident as a despicable attack on a vulnerable woman and said it was “terrying” for the mum-of-one.Mr Islett told one boy: “She didn’t know what was going to happen or what the outcome was going to be.  You have got to put yourself in the victim’s place and consider your actions and the effect it might have on them.” Janice was sitting in a park when she was approached by Semple and the group. Ipswich Youth Court heard they began asking questions about drugs before one of the boys spat in her face. Prosecutor Wayne Ablett said: He came from behind the bench and spat at her, with spit landing on her face. She said, What did you do that for  She recalls the boy laughing at her, then spitting at her again. Magistrates heard the group disappeared for around  minutes, then ed with flour bought at a nearby shop. Mr Ablett said: These items were chucked at and thrown at her body, covering her completely in flour. The boys were still laughing. She was spat at again and one of them had taken a photo of her. She heard one of them say, Were filming it.  The boys were arrested after the incriminating photo appeared on Facebook in July this year. Janice suffered no physical injuries but was left severely distressed by her ordeal. Semple, who admitted threatening behaviour, lives in Bury St Edmunds with his mum. The court heard since the incident he had received death threats, and felt remorseful and sorry for what happened. Declan Gallagher, defending Semple, said: He took the photograph and put it on his own Snapchat. One of his circle then took a screenshot of that, then it went onto Facebook, then it went beyond. He was released on bail, to be sentenced at an adult court on December . Four other boys, aged , ,  and , admitted the same offence yesterday and were sentenced to -month referral orders. story: NewsText messages sent by couple who left baby girl to die in monstrous cage revealedLauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were found guilty of child cruelty at Liverpool Crown CourtShareCommentsByJonathan Humphries:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEllie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle was cleared of manslaughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailText messages sent by a mum and her boyfriend who left a baby girl to die in a monstrous cage have been revealed. Ellie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were cleared of manslaughter, the Liverpool Echo reported. story: NewsTower of London lit up by , flames in poignant tribute to fallen WWI heroesThe flames filled the empty moat which encircles the Tower of London and the ceremony was held to mark the end of WWIShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video tower-london-lights-first-flame-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tower of London was bathed in the light of around , flames which filled the empty moat encircling the landmark to mark the centenary of the end of the First World War. A ceremonial Beefeater guard began the lighting ceremony by bringing a flame down from the tower into the moat, which had been submerged in smoke. Dozens of representatives from the armed forces and volunteers then used the flame to ignite thousands of other torches staked into or placed on the ground underneath the tower, bathing the barren moat in light. Midshipman Balraj Dhanda of the Royal Navy, a volunteer who helped light the flames, described the spectacle as really, really powerful.  I think it creates the right atmosphere for people to have their own personal reflections and gives people time with their own thoughts, he added. It took around  minutes to light the flames, which then burn for roughly four hours. The ceremony was accompanied by a specially commissioned sound installation featuring choral music, as well as words from war poet Mary Bordens Sonnets To A Soldier. The ceremony was amazing, according to Dick Harrold, governor of the Tower of London.  He added: What is so special about it is it means many dferent things. The message with the sound is not focused so much on those that were lost, but those that were left behind, the bereaved and others who were affected by war. The success of the  display of poppies at the tower meant Historic Royal Palaces, who maintain the landmark, were keen to mark the centenary of Armistice. He added: But, of course, we couldnt do poppies again. Spectators gathered on vantage points around the tower to witness the spectacle.  A minutes silence was also observed. The ceremony, named Beyond The Deepening Shadow, will be repeated each night until the final showing on Remembrance Sunday. Members of the public can watch the spectacle for free.
